byline.contributor: Matthew Rosenberg reported from Washington, and Ben Hubbard from Beirut, Lebanon. Hwaida Saad and Anne Barnard contributed reporting from Beirut.
byline.original: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG and BEN HUBBARD

abstract: Nuclear agreement with Iran is unlikely to immediately alter violent reality in the Middle East, or to thaw ongoing tensions with the Untied States and its allies over separate issues; national security establishment will continue to perceive Iran as adversary that needs to be contained; allies like Israel and Saudi Arabia have expressed concern that lifted sanctions will embolden Iran to ramp up support for militant proxies.
lead_paragraph: President Obama now faces the challenge of placating regional allies who fear that sanction relief will embolden Iran to ramp up support for its most militant proxies.

headline.main: Middle East Allies See Heightened Peril in Newly Empowered Tehran
headline.print_headline: Middle East Allies See Heightened Peril in Newly Empowered, Emboldened Tehran

snippet: President Obama now faces the challenge of placating regional allies who fear that sanction relief will embolden Iran to ramp up support for its most militant proxies.
